seriesStmt.title: The Northern Star, and National Trades’ Journal

div.p: Brussels. — A democratic supper was held on Monday, 26th Sept., at the Estaminet Liegeois. There were present Belgians, Frenchmen, Swiss, Poles, Italians, and even a Russian. M. Gottrand, ancient member of the Constituant Congress of Belgium (in 1831) took the chair, General Mellinet having declined. He was assisted by Messrs Imbert, former editor of the Peuple Souverain, of Marseilles (French), and Engels (German), vice-presidents. The principal toasts drank were: — “The Martyrs of Liberty”, by M. Imbert. “The Memory of the French Jacobin Revolution of 1792 and 1793”, by M. Engels. “The English Democracy — may they send us a representative to our next fraternal meeting”, by M. Spilthoorn, of Ghent. “Death to the Jesuits of all kinds”, by M. Marty, Swiss. “The union of all people”, by M. Wallan, president of the German Working Men’s Society. M. Bartels, of Brussels, proposed to make the coming anniversary of the Polish Revolution, a fraternal demonstration, in which democrats of all nations should partake. Another motion was proposed — that a Democratic Society, representing as much as possible all nations, should be formed. Both motions were agreed to.
